content.question: How does the seasonal variation of the ITCZ location over the oceans compare to the variation over land?

options.A: The variation is almost none over the oceans due to the currents in the water.
options.B: The variation is larger over the oceans due to the increased trade winds.
options.C: The variation is smaller because the ocean temperature varies less than the land temperature.
options.D: The ITCZ movement is opposite between land and oceans.

key_points: The ITCZ follows The Sun in that the position varies seasonally
This is because the ITCZ is the culmination of the hottest places in the world for a particular longitude, the "thermal equator" as it is often known, and this moves with the Sun a lot
It moves North in the Northern Hemisphere Summer and South in the Northern Hemisphere Winter
learning.explanation: The ITCZ follows The Sun in that the position varies seasonally. This is because the ITCZ is the culmination of the hottest places in the world for a particular longitude, the "thermal equator" as it is often known, and this moves with the Sun a lot. It moves North in the Northern Hemisphere Summer and South in the Northern Hemisphere Winter. The ITCZ is subject to large seasonal movement overland, but much less over the sea. This is because water has a much higher specific heat capacity than rock, so builds up and loses temperature much slower than land does (about 4x slower), and the oceans have some mixing which makes the effect even stronger. This means that the "hottest" part of the ocean does not move much between December and June, whereas the "hottest" part of the land moves a long way (following The Sun). This "hottest" part of the surface dictates the ITCZ in that area, the "thermal equator".

key_points: Trade winds are consistent winds converging to the equatorial trough from the subtropical high belt on each side of it
The turning effect of geostrophic force (Coriolis) causes northeast trades in the Northern Hemisphere and southeast trades in the Southern
The trade winds blow towards the thermal equator and will therefore change direction when crossing the geographic equator
learning.explanation: Trade winds are consistent winds converging to the equatorial trough from the subtropical high belt on each side of it. The turning effect of geostrophic force (Coriolis) causes northeast trades in the Northern Hemisphere and southeast trades in the Southern. The trade winds blow towards the thermal equator and will therefore change direction when crossing the geographic equator. NE trades will back; SE trades will veer. They are low level winds - considered to exist up to about 10 000 ft. They are most pronounced over the oceans due to the homogeneous surface and little friction. ITCZ = doldrums = Thermal Equator = Equatorial Trough

key_points: FOEHN EFFECT Foehn winds are warm and dry, gusty winds that periodically descends the leeward slopes of nearly all mountains and mountain ranges (warm katabatic wind)
This is a change from wet and cold conditions one side of a mountain, to warmer and drier conditions on the other (leeward) side
- How does it form? When air is forced upwards over elevated terrain (upwind side of the mountain, in this case, the south), it expands and cools adiabatically (at the DALR) until it saturates
learning.explanation: FOEHN EFFECT Foehn winds are warm and dry, gusty winds that periodically descends the leeward slopes of nearly all mountains and mountain ranges (warm katabatic wind). This is a change from wet and cold conditions one side of a mountain, to warmer and drier conditions on the other (leeward) side. - How does it form? When air is forced upwards over elevated terrain (upwind side of the mountain, in this case, the south), it expands and cools adiabatically (at the DALR) until it saturates. After saturation, it will continue to cool at the SALR. Since colder air can hold less water vapour, moisture condenses to form clouds and precipitates as rain/snow above the mountain’s upwind slopes. By the time it reaches the peak and stops climbing, the air is quite dry. As the air makes its leeward descent, it is compressed and warms rapidly all the way downslope – because there is little water left to evaporate. Thus, the air is warmer and drier when it reaches the leeward slope than when it begins its windward ascent. On the windward side we can expect low cloud and precipitation whilst on the leeward side we will see clear turbulent conditions. With regards to this question, with a south wind - the south side is the upwind side => where the air is forced up the mountains, cooling down and condensing - forming clouds. The north side is the leeward/downwind side, where air descends and becomes drier and warmer => little or no precipitation is expected.

learning.explanation: In Summer – June, July and August, the ITCZ moves further north, away from the Equator. As the SE trade wind crosses the equator, it veers to SW – giving rise to the SW Monsoon. The NE Monsoon gives clear weather over central India, Burma and Thailand.

learning.explanation: In late August, India will be affected by the SW Monsoon - with its long sea track over the tropical oceans will pick up moisture and produce very wet conditions, convective clouds and associated TS activity. Further information: MONSOONS A monsoon is a seasonal change in the direction of the prevailing, or strongest, winds of a region. Monsoons lead to distinct wet and dry seasons throughout much of the tropics and are most often associated with the Indian Ocean. Weather depends very much on the track followed. There are three monsoon flows; the NE, NW & SW. NE MONSOON: In winter – December, January and February, the ITCZ moves further south. Winds blow from the winter Siberian high – bringing cool and dry continental air. The NE Monsoon gives clear weather over central India, Burma and Thailand. It also affects SE India, Sri Lanka & east coast of West Malaysia. However, in these locations, the over sea tracks pick up moisture which produces convective clouds and thunderstorms (when crossing mountain ranges). NW MONSOON: When crossing the Equator, NE Monsoon backs, giving rise to the NW Monsoon which brings Convective clouds (Cu, Cb) and thunderstorms to North Australia and New Guinea. SW MONSOON: In Summer – June, July and August, the ITCZ moves further north, away from the Equator. As the SE trade wind crosses the equator, it veers to SW – giving rise to the SW Monsoon. This Monsoon has a long sea track where it picks up moisture, producing heavy Cumulus and Cumulonimbus clouds with heavy thunderstorms, low cloud bases and severe turbulence (having more serious effects on flying than the NE Monsoon). The SW Monsoon affects all of India, Sri Lanka, Burma, exposed coasts of West Malaysia and West African coast (Guinea, Ghana and North Nigeria).

learning.explanation: The Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) is a belt of low pressure which circles the Earth generally near the equator where the trade winds of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres come together. As the air rises, it cools, causing persistent bands of showers and storms around the Earth’s midsection. The main feature of the ITCZ is extensive Cu, Cb and thunderstorms => giving rise to the heavy rains in the tropical regions. When stable air exists, there will be extensive sheets of As & Ns cloud and more continuous type rain. Turbulence is usually severe, as is icing, which can be from 16 000 ft upwards.

content.question: The presence of altocumulus lenticularis is an indication of the..

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.02.05.01.04: Explain how mountain waves may be identified by their associated meteorological phenomena. Having fast airflow over a mountain causes a lot of vertical movement of air, with large updrafts on the windward side of the mountain as the air climbs, as well as large downdrafts on the lee side where the air descends back to the surface. These "mountain waves" often continue downwind of the high ground similar to waves on the ocean, and can have this up and down "wave" motion for hundreds of miles in some cases. The downdrafts within these waves can be so powerful that lower performance aircraft may not be able to climb at all when within one. Mountain waves (or standing waves) are therefore very dangerous to aircraft, and if the right conditions exist, mountain waves can continue as high as the tropopause in some cases. There are some tell-tale signs of mountain waves though. Lenticular clouds (cloud type lenticularis) are clouds which are shaped like a lens, and they stay in the same location, even though the wind in their location is strong. They are indicative of the presence of mountain waves, and look very smooth, but actually contain lots of windshear and turbulence nearby and within them. Wind rotors exist in the region of lenticular clouds, and sometimes have associated roll/rotor clouds, which are also indicative of severe turbulence.

content.question: A strong inversion in the middle section of the troposphere would _____ the vertical development of a Cumulonimbus cloud.

key_points: Note: We have incomplete feedback about this question, and particularly the options available
Please send us any further feedback you can remember from the real exam via the comments, your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions
com, so we can verify and improve the question, thank you! A Cumulonimbus cloud (CB) is the type that forms storms
learning.explanation: Note: We have incomplete feedback about this question, and particularly the options available. Please send us any further feedback you can remember from the real exam via the comments, your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, so we can verify and improve the question, thank you! A Cumulonimbus cloud (CB) is the type that forms storms. For a CB to form, there must be three things; instability, moisture, and a trigger (something which forces air to rise). When the cloud forms and the air is rising in an unstable air mass, the rising air does not cool down at the same rate as the surrounding environment, and this is what we call instability. This means that the rising air wants to continue rising with more and more velocity. When instability and moisture are great enough, these clouds can form large CBs, which continue to accelerate as long as instability exists. If the air becomes more stable, then the cloud's development will slow down (as it no longer has as much of a temperature difference with the surrounding air. This is most commonly seen at the tropopause, where the surrounding air temperature stops changing (an isothermal layer), and all CBs are stopped at the tropopause, flowing outwards to form an "anvil" shape (sometimes overshooting with a small "hat" from the excess velocity). Isothermal layers are inherently very stable, as the rising air cools as it rises, so will never be the same temperature as air which remains the same temperature. This means that inversions are even more stable. Stability is based on the environmental lapse rate (ELR - the rate at which the surrounding air cools with temperature) vs the Dry or Wet Adiabatic Lapse Rate (DALR or SALR) of the rising parcel of air. The DALR is constant and the SALR is close to constant, but the ELR varies massively. The greater the ELR (greater temperature drop per 1000 ft), the less stable the atmosphere. When the ELR is 0 (isothermal layer), or an inversion occurs, the air is absolutely stable. A strong inversion in the mid layers of the troposphere (so 10 - 20,000 ft) would stop a CB's development very quickly indeed. All of a sudden, the rising air in the CB would not be warmer than the surrounding air, and would stop or sink instead of rising. The cloud would have no further development above this point.

options.C: Inflow of warm air at higher levels, reducing relative humidity.
options.D: Inflow of unstable air, dissipating any surface inversion.

key_points: STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE)
occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions
It is caused when low-level cold air from a land mass moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea (water surface) = advection of very cold air over a warm sea
learning.explanation: STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE). occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions. It is caused when low-level cold air from a land mass moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea (water surface) = advection of very cold air over a warm sea. The small amount of evaporation from the sea in the cold air just above it is enough to cause saturation and condensation. Steam fog is typically up to 500 feet thick and may drift inland. It forms in conditions of no wind or very light winds. It will be dispersed by an increase/decrease in wind speed or change of direction. It will also be dispersed if the water becomes colder or the air becomes warmer (the temperature difference reduces). To look at each option: "Radiation cooling and the creation of a ground inversion." This means that the low-level air is getting colder, which would not dissipate the sea smoke. "Calm winds, allowing the build-up of high-level stratus clouds." Calm winds allow the formation of sea smoke, and high level clouds do not really affect it. "Inflow of warm air at higher levels, reducing relative humidity." High level changes do not affect sea smoke formation/dissipation. It is a low-level phenomenon only. "Inflow of unstable air, dissipating any surface inversion." This is correct. Unstable air without a surface inversion will be warmer near the surface, so the sea smoke will dissipate as the air temperature rises above the dewpoint.

key_points: Cumulus clouds form primarily through the process of convection
It begins when the Earth's surface is heated by the sun, warming the air just above it
Warm air is lighter and less dense than cool air, so it begins to rise
learning.explanation: Cumulus clouds form primarily through the process of convection. It begins when the Earth's surface is heated by the sun, warming the air just above it. Warm air is lighter and less dense than cool air, so it begins to rise. As the warm air rises, it cools adiabatically (without gaining or losing heat), and when it reaches its dew point temperature (the temperature at which air becomes saturated with moisture), water vapor starts to condense into tiny water droplets. These droplets cluster together to form visible cumulus clouds. These clouds can grow rapidly, when the atmosphere is unstable, with no upper-air inversion, and may develop into cumulonimbus clouds, with their tops reaching the tropopause. The vertical extent of cumulus clouds is limited by the stability of the atmosphere. If the atmosphere is stable, meaning that the temperature increases with height (inversion). A subsidence inversion occurs when there is a layer of sinking or subsiding air in the atmosphere. This sinking air warms adiabatically (without heat exchange) as it descends, causing a temperature increase with height. This warm layer acts as a lid or cap on the rising warm air, preventing it from ascending further.

content.question: Fog or mist will start to form when the air becomes saturated, this may happen when: Temperature (1) _____ to the dew point temperature and/or there is (2) _____ in dew point temperature to that of the air temperature.

key_points: Dew, fog or clouds form when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into liquid water

For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated (Relative Humidity = 100%) - which means that the air parcel is unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense
There are two ways by which saturation is reached: (a) By increasing the water content in the air
learning.explanation: Dew, fog or clouds form when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into liquid water. For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated (Relative Humidity = 100%) - which means that the air parcel is unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense. There are two ways by which saturation is reached: (a) By increasing the water content in the air. I.e. through evaporation, to a point where the air can hold no more. (b) By cooling the air so that it reaches its dew point - this is the temperature at which condensation occurs, and is unable to "hold" any more water. The dew point is always lower than (or equal to) the air temperature => If the air temperature cools to the dew point, or if the dew point rises to equal the air temperature, then water vapour condenses and dew, fog or clouds begin to form. At this point where the dew point temperature equals the air temperature, the relative humidity is 100%. For condensation to occur, temperature must equal dew point.

content.question:
In a situation with a high relative humidity, the cloud base is located relatively ___ and its top is situated where the ___ meets the ___.
Fill in the blanks.

key_points: To have a rough idea on the Cloud Base height, we can refer to the following formula: (Air temperature at surface – dew point temperature) x 400 A general rule of thumb is that the wider the gap between the temperature and dew point, the higher the cloud base is likely to be
When temperature rises during the day, dew point spread will increase and cloud base will be higher
When Relative Humidity is low, you would expect a HIGH cloud base
learning.explanation: To have a rough idea on the Cloud Base height, we can refer to the following formula: (Air temperature at surface – dew point temperature) x 400 A general rule of thumb is that the wider the gap between the temperature and dew point, the higher the cloud base is likely to be. When temperature rises during the day, dew point spread will increase and cloud base will be higher. When Relative Humidity is low, you would expect a HIGH cloud base. On the other hand, a lower difference between temperature and dew point (and, consequently, High Relative Humidity), leads to a LOWer cloud base. To calculate cloud tops, we need to know the SALR and ELR => cloud tops are located where SALR meets ELR. Why? Because air in clouds is rising with SALR - air is saturated (moist). Saturated air cools down slower and as long as enough moisture is available the cloud will keep growing. When SALR = ELR (temperature of air parcel in cloud = temperature of environment) the parcel of air cannot ascend (rise) any more because there is no difference in temperature (no difference in density). Hence, top of clouds is defined.

content.question: "Frontal fog" may occur when low cloud covers the surface with the passage of a front, more commonly over hills than over low ground. It may also develop when...

options.A: dust particles blown by strong winds at a cold front become condensation nuclei for water droplets.
options.B: the air becomes saturated by continuous rain falling from warm air above a frontal surface.
options.C: cold air crossing warm, damp ground absorbs water vapour, which then recondenses in the cold air.
options.D: a cold front cools the warm air it displaces, at the surface, to below its dew point.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.02.05.01: Explain the formation of frontal fog. Frontal fog is a term that can be used to describe any fog that was caused by frontal activity, so includes the "hill fog" mentioned in the question, which is actually just cloud that is low enough to touch the high ground. The more common definition of frontal fog is a special type of fog that only happens under a warm front, just before it passes. Before a warm front passes, we are in a cold sector, so the air is cold, and therefore the ground is relatively cold as well. There is, however, warmer rain falling from above, at least towards the latter stages of the front passing. This is warm rain falling through cold air, and tends to bring a high amount of humidity to the air it goes through. This humidity is most when the warm rain hits the cold ground and begins to evaporate. At this point, we have a lot of humidity in cold air, which leads to the air becoming quickly saturated, and frontal fog is formed. Sometimes this is complemented by stratus fractus, which are small patches of stratus cloud that hang in the air.

content.question: Which type of inversion can lead to fog formation due to the temperature of air in contact with the surface dropping below its dew point when it contacts a colder surface?

key_points: An inversion in the atmosphere is where temperature rises with an increase in height
This produces extreme stability There are four kinds of inversions: ground, turbulence, subsidence, and frontal

GROUND INVERSION - develops when air is cooled by contact with a colder surface until it becomes cooler than the overlying atmosphere; this occurs most often on clear nights, when the ground cools off rapidly by radiation
learning.explanation: An inversion in the atmosphere is where temperature rises with an increase in height. This produces extreme stability There are four kinds of inversions: ground, turbulence, subsidence, and frontal. GROUND INVERSION - develops when air is cooled by contact with a colder surface until it becomes cooler than the overlying atmosphere; this occurs most often on clear nights, when the ground cools off rapidly by radiation. If the temperature of surface air drops below its dew point, fog may result. TURBULENCE INVERSION - often forms when quiescent air overlies turbulent air. Within the turbulent layer, vertical mixing carries heat downward and cools the upper part of the layer. The unmixed air above is not cooled and eventually is warmer than the air below; an inversion then exists. SUBSIDENCE INVERSION - develops when a widespread layer of air descends. The layer is compressed and heated by the resulting increase in atmospheric pressure, and, as a result, the lapse rate of temperature is reduced. If the air mass sinks low enough, the air at higher altitudes becomes warmer than at lower altitudes, producing a temperature inversion. FRONTAL INVERSION - occurs when a cold air mass undercuts a warm air mass and lifts it aloft; the front between the two air masses then has warm air above and cold air below.

High-level cirriform clouds like cirrus (Ci), cirrostratus (Cs), or cirrocumulus (Cc) clouds have a low concentration of ice crystals and do not pose a significant risk of icing or turbulence

learning.explanation: Cirriform clouds, which are thin and feather-like with patches or narrow bands, consist of small ice crystals. High-level cirriform clouds like cirrus (Ci), cirrostratus (Cs), or cirrocumulus (Cc) clouds have a low concentration of ice crystals and do not pose a significant risk of icing or turbulence. It is important to note that the question specifically pertains to cirriform clouds. Ice crystal icing typically occurs in large-scale convective systems like thunderstorms and not in cirriform clouds. Hence, the correct answer selected is "Unlikely to be a problem as these clouds are usually composed of ice crystals, therefore icing on the airframe or engines is unlikely to occur."

key_points: Cumulus clouds are formed through the process of convection
Convection involves the vertical movement of air masses, particularly the rising of warm air
The trigger for the formation of cumulus clouds is heating from below
learning.explanation: Cumulus clouds are formed through the process of convection. Convection involves the vertical movement of air masses, particularly the rising of warm air. The trigger for the formation of cumulus clouds is heating from below. This heating can occur due to the warming of the Earth's surface by sunlight. As the surface heats up, it warms the air above it. When this warm air rises, it cools and condenses to form cumulus clouds. The vertical growth of cumulus clouds is restricted by a subsidence inversion. A subsidence inversion occurs when descending air in the atmosphere creates a layer of warmer air above cooler air. This layer acts as a barrier to vertical air movement, preventing further upward growth of the cumulus cloud. It inhibits the vertical development of the cloud, leading to the characteristic flattened appearance of cumulus clouds.

key_points: CUMULUS HUMILIS, often referred to as "fair weather cumulus", are cumuliform clouds with little vertical extent, common in the summer - formed by local heating of the surface, even in a stable atmosphere
They are fairly distinct and easy to classify in relation to other clouds: they’re a cumulus cloud that’s wider than tall
They’re flattened cumulus and are generally found low in altitude
learning.explanation: CUMULUS HUMILIS, often referred to as "fair weather cumulus", are cumuliform clouds with little vertical extent, common in the summer - formed by local heating of the surface, even in a stable atmosphere. They are fairly distinct and easy to classify in relation to other clouds: they’re a cumulus cloud that’s wider than tall. They’re flattened cumulus and are generally found low in altitude. Its vertical growth is usually restricted by the existence of a temperature inversion in the atmosphere - cooling of the surface stops convection and increases stability in the airmass which causes clouds to dissipate. Within the cloud, ascending currents of about 2–5 m/s (7–17 ft/s) may be encountered. Turbulence is sometimes severe, especially during the formation and growth of the cloud, and it diminishes when the cloud is mature. Air below the cloud base can be quite turbulent due to the thermals that formed the clouds, giving occupants of light aircraft an uncomfortable ride. To avoid turbulence where such clouds are present, pilots may climb above the cloud tops.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.02.04.01: Explain the formation of sea smoke. STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE). occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions. It is caused when cold air (usually from a land mass) moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea = advection of very cold air over warm water. The small amount of evaporation from the sea is enough to cause saturation and condensation in the air close to the surface. A surface inversion has to be in place (and is usually because of cooling from the cold land mass) so this sea smoke does not continue rising into clouds. Steam fog is typically up to 500 feet thick and may drift inland. Forms in conditions of no wind or very light winds. Will be dispersed by an increase/decrease in wind speed or certain change of wind direction. Whereas clouds and fog are usually formed due to cooling of air, this is a case of fog being formed by increasing the humidity of the air. The best way to remember sea smoke is to think of a hot tub in a very cold climate, it forms "steam fog" in the same way that sea smoke occurs, just with a bigger temperature difference.

content.question: What causes cumulus clouds to stop growing in the evening?

options.A: Reduced convection due to less solar radiation.
options.B: Inversions forming at the top of each cloud.
options.C: A change in the rate of adiabatic heating.
options.D: Formation of an inversion at the tropopause.

key_points: In an unstable air mass, cumulus clouds will often form during the day, particularly due to surface heating, causing localised thermal uplift and then convection due to the instability of the air mass

When the Sun becomes lower in the sky in an evening, the solar heating on the ground decreases, which reduces thermal uplift, as well as reducing low level heating of the air mass, which increases the stability of the air mass
All this reduces the convection of cumulus clouds, and gradually stops them growing any further, or new ones forming
learning.explanation: In an unstable air mass, cumulus clouds will often form during the day, particularly due to surface heating, causing localised thermal uplift and then convection due to the instability of the air mass. When the Sun becomes lower in the sky in an evening, the solar heating on the ground decreases, which reduces thermal uplift, as well as reducing low level heating of the air mass, which increases the stability of the air mass. All this reduces the convection of cumulus clouds, and gradually stops them growing any further, or new ones forming. Sometimes, if there have been large CB clouds formed during the late afternoon, they will have enough momentum and energy left in them to continue producing thunderstorms into the late evening and night.

learning.explanation: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of clouds, preventing further upward convection. learning.explanation: As water condenses, changing from water vapour to the liquid state – it releases energy, in the form of latent heat, to its surroundings. Further heating the surrounding air, leads to more convection and rising of the clouds to higher altitudes. If sufficient moisture is present to condense, the cloud mass could rise through several levels – before it encounters the boundary between the troposphere and the stratosphere – TROPOPAUSE. The top of the troposphere, called the tropopause, corresponds to the level in which the pattern of decreasing temperature with height ceases. And beyond this boundary, the air no longer gets colder with increasing altitude and supresses further upward motion of the cloud mass. The cloud tops will, therefore, flatten and spread into an anvil shape.

content.question: The top of a stratus cloud is typically upheld by a capping (1)_____ situated (2)_____ the cloud's top.

key_points: Under normal ISA conditions, warm air ascends until it reaches its condensation point, at which clouds form and the heat released during condensation continues to propel the upward movement of the air
Once all the moisture has condensed, cloud formation ceases
However, the presence of an inversion, often referred to as an isothermal layer, disrupts this upward motion
learning.explanation: Under normal ISA conditions, warm air ascends until it reaches its condensation point, at which clouds form and the heat released during condensation continues to propel the upward movement of the air. Once all the moisture has condensed, cloud formation ceases. However, the presence of an inversion, often referred to as an isothermal layer, disrupts this upward motion. Inversions occur when the rising air encounters a layer of air that is warmer, causing it to halt its ascent. Consequently, inversions frequently cap clouds and fog layers. Moreover, an inversion inhibits the vertical movement of other atmospheric particles contained within the air pocket. As a result, an area above an inversion layer typically remains clear of clouds, smog, mist, and haze, among other things. In addition, there is an increase in wind speed above the inversion compared to just below it, resulting in significant wind shear at the inversion layer.

content.question: In mid-latitudes, the tops of cumulus are often limited by:

key_points: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of cloud, preventing further upward convection

Basically, up and down currents within clouds, which lead to their vertical development, are decided by humidity and temperature differences (between the cloud and the surroundings) - if the air temperature is equal or higher than the cloud's temperature, clouds will stop growing
In simple words, a temperature inversion is a thin layer of the atmosphere where the normal decrease in temperature with height switches to the temperature increasing with height
learning.explanation: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of cloud, preventing further upward convection. Basically, up and down currents within clouds, which lead to their vertical development, are decided by humidity and temperature differences (between the cloud and the surroundings) - if the air temperature is equal or higher than the cloud's temperature, clouds will stop growing. In simple words, a temperature inversion is a thin layer of the atmosphere where the normal decrease in temperature with height switches to the temperature increasing with height. It acts like a lid, keeping normal convective overturning of the atmosphere from penetrating through the inversion. Some of the effects it might have: An inversion might cause clouds just below the inversion to spread out and take on a flattened appearance. Still another effect is to prevent thunderstorms from forming. Even in an air mass that is hot and humid in the lowest layers, thunderstorms will be prevented if an inversion in the lower atmosphere is keeping this air from rising. The conceptual opposite of a temperature inversion is an unstable air layer.

Early feedback and knowledge leaned on the side of "Diurnal solar heating", but most recent feedback shows the cold front to be the correct answer. See the comments for the most recent feedback. UPDATE: The Hungarian CAA have approved an appeal based on this question (which said that two correct answers were present), stating, "The cold front is the right option, because clearance occurs with a change of air mass, or less commonly with an increase in surface wind. The term "on its own” means the weather phenomena associated with cold front. Of course not the definition of cold front will improve the visibility, but the phenomena. Hovewer diurnal solar heating can also be a correct answer." We think that the cold front and diurnal solar heating are both perfectly correct, so we hope that they have removed this question from the database now. If this comes up in an exam, you may appeal it, quoting the Hungarian CAA above if necessary. Advection fog is formed by the advection of warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion. The surface can be land or sea and it can appear by day or night. Most commonly, the dissipation of advection fog is by a change of air mass, replacing the moist air with dry air. For example, in this question, the movement of a cold front would mean that the new air is not the same air than cooled overnight close to the ground, and so the advection fog will dissipate. However, sometimes solar heating on the land is sufficient to raise the temperature to the condensation point and the fog evaporates.

content.question: An air mass containing St and Sc clouds is cooling as it is lifted over high ground. Which of the following will happen to the concentration of water droplets or ice particles?

options.C: The concentration will remain the same.

key_points: Air contains a certain amount of water held in vapour form - its humidity
Warmer air can hold more water vapour than cooler air can, so the humidity is often measured relative to how much that parcel of air can hold

If an air mass gets cooler and the relative humidity passes 100% (past the amount it can hold), the excess water will begin to condense as droplets (or depose into ice crystals directly if cold enough)
learning.explanation: Air contains a certain amount of water held in vapour form - its humidity. Warmer air can hold more water vapour than cooler air can, so the humidity is often measured relative to how much that parcel of air can hold. If an air mass gets cooler and the relative humidity passes 100% (past the amount it can hold), the excess water will begin to condense as droplets (or depose into ice crystals directly if cold enough). This forms clouds, when the temperature drops below the dew point as air rises. As the clouds are being forced to rise by the terrain (and we have not been told that precipitation has yet begun to fall), the airmass is cooling, and the colder air will not be able to hold as much moisture in vapour form, so more and more of the stored vapour will condense into droplets or ice crystals (depending on the freezing level). As this is unlikely to make the current droplets/crystals larger due to the rate of coalescence usually being lower than the rate of droplet formation, the only possible correct answer is that the concentration of droplets/crystals in the cloud will increase.

key_points: CLOUD FORMATION Cloud is formed by air being lifted and cooled adiabatically until the water vapour condenses out as water droplets
In other words, when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into visible water droplets or ice crystals
For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated => unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense into a liquid or solid form
learning.explanation: CLOUD FORMATION Cloud is formed by air being lifted and cooled adiabatically until the water vapour condenses out as water droplets. In other words, when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into visible water droplets or ice crystals. For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated => unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense into a liquid or solid form. The height at which this occurs is called the condensation level - it is also the height of the cloud base. The condensation level is the height at which the rising air, cooling adiabatically, has cooled to the dew point temperature. Any further ascent and cooling will result in condensation and the formation of cloud. There are two ways by which saturation is reached. (a) By increasing the water content in the air, e.g. through evaporation, to a point where the air can hold no more. (b) By cooling the air so that it reaches its dew point - this is the temperature at which condensation occurs, and is unable to 'hold' any more water. => Therefore, we can conclude that 2 unsaturated parcels of air will form a cloud when they cool down to the dew point temperature, becoming saturated => and condensation starts.

learning.explanation: STEAMING FOG (ARCTIC SMOKE). occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions. content.question: Freezing fog consists of:

key_points: FREEZING FOG
In its simplest sense, fog is a cloud near the ground that consists of tiny liquid water droplets
Fog can form when moisture is added into the air or the air cools to a point that it becomes saturated
learning.explanation: FREEZING FOG. In its simplest sense, fog is a cloud near the ground that consists of tiny liquid water droplets. Fog can form when moisture is added into the air or the air cools to a point that it becomes saturated. Freezing fog occurs when fog forms in temperatures that are below freezing, and the tiny water droplets in the air remain as liquid. They become supercooled water droplets remaining liquid even though they are below freezing temperature. This occurs because liquid needs a surface to freeze upon. When droplets from freezing fog freeze onto surfaces, a white deposit of feathery ice crystals is formed. This is referred to as rime; rime is a characteristic of freezing fog and is often seen on vertical surfaces exposed to the wind.

content.question: Which of the following limits the upwards growth of stratiform clouds?

options.A: An inversion below the cloud top.
options.B: An inversion above the cloud top.
options.C: Adiabatic heating above the cloud top.
options.D: Adiabatic heating below the cloud top.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.01.03.02: Explain the influence of an inversion on the formation of stratus clouds. In the troposphere, inversions cause an incredibly stable layer of atmosphere, which reduces the upwards motion of cumuliform clouds, and limits the vertical extent of stratiform clouds completely. Stratiform clouds can form for many reasons, such as turbulence in the air causing mixing, orographic or frontal uplift, etc., but they always occur in a stable layer of atmosphere. When the air gets pushed up or mixed up enough to reach its dewpoint, the cloud base forms, and if the air is raised above this, then the cloud continues upwards as high as the air is pushed/mixed. An inversion, however, is much too stable, and any air moving into the inversion will either fall back out of the layer, as the layer is a lot warmer than the air below (preventing mixing of the air), or just warm up above the dewpoint and stop forming cloud. This means that stratiform clouds remain below an inversion in the atmosphere, and this limits their growth.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to question 501937, but with answers that are different enough to warrant a separate question here
We have some slightly conflicting feedback about wording for this one, so please let us know if you see either question in the exam, and what you can remember about them, thank you! RADIATION FOG
Caused by radiation of the earth’s heat at night, and the conductive cooling below dew point of the air in contact with the ground, in conditions of calm or very light wind and clear skies
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to question 501937, but with answers that are different enough to warrant a separate question here. We have some slightly conflicting feedback about wording for this one, so please let us know if you see either question in the exam, and what you can remember about them, thank you! RADIATION FOG. Caused by radiation of the earth’s heat at night, and the conductive cooling below dew point of the air in contact with the ground, in conditions of calm or very light wind and clear skies. Radiation fog occurs at night and early morning and usually does not last long after sunrise (about 30 minutes). Predominantly occurring in autumn and winter. The cooling of air close to the ground causes that air to drop below the temperature of the air just above it (which is not touching the ground), causing a very low-level inversion, known as a ground inversion. Inversions are very stable areas, and these ones in particular create radiation fog when the cold air inside the inversion drops below its dewpoint CONDITIONS NECESSARY FOR RADIATION FOG TO FORM Clear sky - increases the rate of terrestrial radiation and cooling of the ground. High relative humidity - little cooling will be enough to cause saturation and condensation into fog. Calm or very light wind – any heavier wind (above 8 kt) causes turbulent mixing of the lower air, breaking up the ground inversion, and lifting the fog into low stratus cloud. Surface - only occurs over land, because ground surface is a much better heat conductor than sea surface. To go through the options: "In the inversion layer there is a lot of turbulence, which causes the formation of fog." There is very little turbulence in an inversion layer. "The decrease of temperature with the height close to the surface is abnormally high." In a ground inversion, the air above the ground increases with height until the top of the inversion is reached, which is the opposite of this option. "The air cools down close to the ground, without any convection." Correct. The air in contact with the ground cools down by conduction, which makes the air close to the ground much colder than the air above it, this is an inversion, and when that air reaches its dew point, fog will form. "In the inversion layer the air is unstable, which allows significant cooling close to the ground. An inversion is always an absolutely stable layer of air.

key_points: Cumulus fractus clouds usually form detached clouds, and are only two thousand to three thousand feet above the earth’s level
Unlike other cumulus clouds, cumulus fractus do not have puffy shapes

learning.explanation: Cumulus fractus clouds usually form detached clouds, and are only two thousand to three thousand feet above the earth’s level. Unlike other cumulus clouds, cumulus fractus do not have puffy shapes. They appear in small fragments with irregular shape, giving an impression as if they are torn or shred. Fractus is very unstable, and also indicates unstable air. As such, they can often signal a change coming in the weather — usually appearing at the leading and trailing edges of summer storms. Observing fractus gives an indication of wind movements under the parent cloud.

key_points: ADVECTION FOG
Is formed by the advection of warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion
The surface can be land or sea and it can appear by day or night
learning.explanation: ADVECTION FOG. Is formed by the advection of warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion. The surface can be land or sea and it can appear by day or night. CONDITIONS NECESSARY FOR ADVECTION FOG TO FORM WIND SPEEDS. Up to 15 kts to move the air (may be stronger over sea – up to 20 kts). Wind speeds over 5 kts are sufficient for advection fog formation, but the speeds of around 15 kts provide the conditions for maximum vertical development of advection fog. COLD SURFACE. Colder than the dew point of the air moving over it – to ensure condensation. Movement of air over damp ground or water surface increases its humidity. HUMID AIR. High relative humidity – so that relatively little cooling is required to produce saturation and subsequent condensation. TEMPERATURE DIFFERENCE. The greater the temperature difference between the warmer air and the colder ground => the greater the likelihood of fog formation.

key_points: A towering cumulus (TCU) cloud typically appears as a large, white, fluffy cloud that can reach great heights
It often has a flat base and a rounded top, and can resemble a "tower" or "mushroom" shape
The cloud may appear to be "boiling" or "bubbling" as it grows and develops
learning.explanation: A towering cumulus (TCU) cloud typically appears as a large, white, fluffy cloud that can reach great heights. It often has a flat base and a rounded top, and can resemble a "tower" or "mushroom" shape. The cloud may appear to be "boiling" or "bubbling" as it grows and develops. It is a type of cumulus cloud that is tall and large, often associated with thunderstorms. TCU indicates the presence of ‘thermals’, and may grow into Cb if conditions are right. One of the key differences in appearance between a towering cumulus and a cumulonimbus cloud is the size. A towering cumulus cloud is a large, white, fluffy cloud that can reach great heights, but it is not as tall and wide as a cumulonimbus cloud. Another difference is that a cumulonimbus cloud often has an anvil-shaped top, which is caused by the cloud reaching the upper limit of the troposphere and the winds spreading the top of the cloud out horizontally. Also, cumulonimbus clouds are more likely to produce thunderstorm and lightning than towering cumulus clouds.

key_points: When a parcel of air cools, its relative humidity increases, eventually reaching 100% relative humidity, which is the point at which the air becomes saturated, and can no longer hold any more water vapour
This condenses as a cloud, which is known as hill fog (orographic fog) when it happens around high elevation ground
The clouds happen at an altitude depending on their relative humidity, the higher the relative humidity at sea level, the lower the clouds occur, making them more likely to exist as orographic fog
learning.explanation: When a parcel of air cools, its relative humidity increases, eventually reaching 100% relative humidity, which is the point at which the air becomes saturated, and can no longer hold any more water vapour. This condenses as a cloud, which is known as hill fog (orographic fog) when it happens around high elevation ground. The clouds happen at an altitude depending on their relative humidity, the higher the relative humidity at sea level, the lower the clouds occur, making them more likely to exist as orographic fog. In this question, the wind is pushing the cooling air up the western slope of the high ground, so that is where orographic fog is most likely to form first.

As the air mass gains altitude it quickly cools down adiabatically, which can raise the relative humidity to 100% and create Orographic clouds (clouds that develop in response to the forced lifting of air by the earth's topography)

- The type of clouds which will be formed depend on the type of air mass: Stable (layer type of clouds will form - STRATIFORM) - great horizontal extension, little vertical development: ST, SC,AS,NS,CI,CS
learning.explanation: As the airflow encounters the mountain range, it is forced to rise; this is referred to as Orographic Lift. As the air mass gains altitude it quickly cools down adiabatically, which can raise the relative humidity to 100% and create Orographic clouds (clouds that develop in response to the forced lifting of air by the earth's topography). - The type of clouds which will be formed depend on the type of air mass: Stable (layer type of clouds will form - STRATIFORM) - great horizontal extension, little vertical development: ST, SC,AS,NS,CI,CS. Unstable (heap type of clouds - CUMULIFORM) - extensive vertical extension: CU,TCU,CB,AC,CC.

learning.explanation: ADVECTION FOG. Is formed by the advection of relatiely warm, moist air over a cold surface – the air mass is cooled from below giving rise to an inversion. Wind speeds over 5 kts are sufficient for advection fog formation, but the speeds of around 15 kts provide the conditions for maximum vertical development of advection fog. COLD SURFACE. Colder than the dew point of the air moving over it – to ensure condensation. Movement of air over damp ground or water surface increases its humidity. HUMID AIR. High relative humidity – so that relatively little cooling is required to produce saturation and subsequent condensation. TEMPERATURE DIFFERENCE. The greater the temperature difference between the warmer air and the colder ground => the greater the likelihood of fog formation. "Morning in autumn with freezing temperature over land but still a couple degrees above freezing over sea, with a slight wind from sea to land" => Relatively warmer air from the sea is advected over colder surface (land)

learning.explanation: 050.05.02.01.08: Explain the relationship between moisture content and visibility during different types of winter precipitation (e.g. large vs small snowflakes). Moisture content and type of precipitation are the main factors of visibility during precipitation. For instance, rain has relatively good visibility, as the light is scattered a little through each raindrop, but they are relatively see through still. More importantly, rain is a very dense form of precipitation, as so there are less raindrops than for a snow shower of the same moisture content. Snow, therefore, has quite poor visibility, depending on the intensity of course. A light snow shower would still have better visibility than a heavy tropical rain shower. For this question, we should consider each option: A) "Visibility in precipitation with large snow flakes is worse than in rain." This is absolutely correct, snow flakes give worse visibility than rain. Large snowflakes are worse still, as they block more light. B) "Visibility in a shower with blowing snow is better than in heavy rain." Blowing snow is where the wind picks up the snow from the ground and the snow which falls during a snow shower, creating very low visibility indeed, as low as 1 metre visibility. Heavy rain is not as bad as this, so this is incorrect. C) "Visibility in heavy snow is better than in drizzle with small water droplets." I think it is quite obvious that visibility is very bad in heavy snow, and not nearly as bad in drizzle, so this is incorrect. D) "Regardless of the moisture content, the visibility in rain is worse than in snow." As discussed above, it is more difficult to see through snow, which is a much less dense form of precipitation, so takes up more space, and is also more opaque than rain. This is therefore incorrect.

learning.explanation: Hail is commonly associated with cumulonimbus (CB) clouds, which exhibit noticeable strong updrafts and downdrafts. Within these CB clouds, precipitation particles have the opportunity to grow larger due to the aggregation of ice crystals and supercooled water droplets, ultimately resulting in the formation of hail. When the size of these ice particles exceeds 5 mm, they are referred to as hailstones. As the hailstones continue to grow, they eventually reach a critical size that cannot be sustained by the upward air currents within the cloud. Consequently, they begin to fall from the cloud toward the ground. However, there is a possibility for hailstones to rise again if they are carried into an area with a strong updraft. This process can lead to the repeated aggregation of supercooled water droplets onto the hailstones, contributing to their further growth. This repeated cycle of aggregation and growth results in the layered structure of hailstones, resembling the layers of a cabbage or an onion. Additionally, the hailstone can also grow through sublimation, where water vapor in the cloud condenses directly onto the hailstone, further increasing its size.

content.question: In cold clouds where ice crystals and cloud droplets coexist, most precipitation starts out as..

key_points: BERGERON PROCESS Describes the process of precipitation formation in the middle and high latitudes
Clouds form at altitudes where the temperatures are below the freezing point of water
In these clouds, water exists in its liquid form even though the temperatures are cold enough to freeze water
learning.explanation: BERGERON PROCESS Describes the process of precipitation formation in the middle and high latitudes. Clouds form at altitudes where the temperatures are below the freezing point of water. In these clouds, water exists in its liquid form even though the temperatures are cold enough to freeze water. Water that has a temperature below freezing but is still in a liquid state is called supercooled water. Ice crystals are found co-existing with the super-cooled water in cold clouds. When this occurs, the ice crystals will grow at the expense of the water droplets. At temperatures below freezing the saturation vapor pressure of ice is less than that over a droplet of water. This means that a water vapor gradient exists between the droplet and the ice. Water can evaporate off the droplet and deposit on the ice in response to the water vapor gradient. The droplet will dissipate in size while the ice crystal grows into a snow flake. Once the snow flake is large enough, it will fall to the surface. Thus, precipitation that falls in the middle and high latitudes starts out as snow. Whether it hits the surface as snow or rain depends on the temperature conditions through which the snowflake falls.

content.question: Mixed clouds are composed of both supercooled water droplets and ice crystals. Most precipitation from these clouds starts out as:

key_points: BERGERON PROCESS Describes the process of precipitation formation in the middle and high latitudes
Clouds form at altitudes where the temperatures are below the freezing point of water
In these clouds, water exists in its liquid form even though the temperatures are cold enough to freeze water
learning.explanation: BERGERON PROCESS Describes the process of precipitation formation in the middle and high latitudes. Clouds form at altitudes where the temperatures are below the freezing point of water. In these clouds, water exists in its liquid form even though the temperatures are cold enough to freeze water. Water that has a temperature below freezing but is still in a liquid state is called supercooled water. Ice crystals are found co-existing with the super-cooled water in cold clouds. When this occurs, the ice crystals will grow at the expense of the water droplets. At temperatures below freezing the saturation vapor pressure of ice is less than that over a droplet of water. This means that a water vapor gradient exists between the droplet and the ice. Water can evaporate off the droplet and deposit on the ice in response to the water vapor gradient. The droplet will dissipate in size while the ice crystal grows into a snow flake. Once the snow flake is large enough, it will fall to the surface. Thus, precipitation that falls in the middle and high latitudes starts out as snow. Whether it hits the surface as snow or rain depends on the temperature conditions through which the snowflake falls.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.02.05.01.04: Explain how mountain waves may be identified by their associated meteorological phenomena. Having fast airflow over a mountain causes a lot of vertical movement of air, with large updrafts on the windward side of the mountain as the air climbs, as well as large downdrafts on the lee side where the air descends back to the surface. These "mountain waves" often continue downwind of the high ground similar to waves on the ocean, and can have this up and down "wave" motion for hundreds of miles in some cases. The downdrafts within these waves can be so powerful that lower performance aircraft may not be able to climb at all when within one. Mountain waves (or standing waves) are therefore very dangerous to aircraft, and if the right conditions exist, mountain waves can continue as high as the tropopause in some cases. There are some tell-tale signs of mountain waves though. Lenticular clouds (cloud type lenticularis) are clouds which are shaped like a lens, and they stay in the same location, even though the wind in their location is strong. They are indicative of the presence of mountain waves, and look very smooth, but actually contain lots of windshear and turbulence nearby and within them. Wind rotors exist in the region of lenticular clouds, and sometimes have associated roll/rotor clouds, which are also indicative of severe turbulence.

content.question: A strong inversion in the middle section of the troposphere would _____ the vertical development of a Cumulonimbus cloud.

key_points: Note: We have incomplete feedback about this question, and particularly the options available
Please send us any further feedback you can remember from the real exam via the comments, your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions
com, so we can verify and improve the question, thank you! A Cumulonimbus cloud (CB) is the type that forms storms
learning.explanation: Note: We have incomplete feedback about this question, and particularly the options available. Please send us any further feedback you can remember from the real exam via the comments, your dashboard, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, so we can verify and improve the question, thank you! A Cumulonimbus cloud (CB) is the type that forms storms. For a CB to form, there must be three things; instability, moisture, and a trigger (something which forces air to rise). When the cloud forms and the air is rising in an unstable air mass, the rising air does not cool down at the same rate as the surrounding environment, and this is what we call instability. This means that the rising air wants to continue rising with more and more velocity. When instability and moisture are great enough, these clouds can form large CBs, which continue to accelerate as long as instability exists. If the air becomes more stable, then the cloud's development will slow down (as it no longer has as much of a temperature difference with the surrounding air. This is most commonly seen at the tropopause, where the surrounding air temperature stops changing (an isothermal layer), and all CBs are stopped at the tropopause, flowing outwards to form an "anvil" shape (sometimes overshooting with a small "hat" from the excess velocity). Isothermal layers are inherently very stable, as the rising air cools as it rises, so will never be the same temperature as air which remains the same temperature. This means that inversions are even more stable. Stability is based on the environmental lapse rate (ELR - the rate at which the surrounding air cools with temperature) vs the Dry or Wet Adiabatic Lapse Rate (DALR or SALR) of the rising parcel of air. The DALR is constant and the SALR is close to constant, but the ELR varies massively. The greater the ELR (greater temperature drop per 1000 ft), the less stable the atmosphere. When the ELR is 0 (isothermal layer), or an inversion occurs, the air is absolutely stable. A strong inversion in the mid layers of the troposphere (so 10 - 20,000 ft) would stop a CB's development very quickly indeed. All of a sudden, the rising air in the CB would not be warmer than the surrounding air, and would stop or sink instead of rising. The cloud would have no further development above this point.

key_points: STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE)
occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions
It is caused when low-level cold air from a land mass moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea (water surface) = advection of very cold air over a warm sea
learning.explanation: STEAM FOG (ARCTIC SEA SMOKE). occurs over sea, mainly in polar regions. It is caused when low-level cold air from a land mass moves over a (comparatively) warmer sea (water surface) = advection of very cold air over a warm sea. The small amount of evaporation from the sea in the cold air just above it is enough to cause saturation and condensation. Steam fog is typically up to 500 feet thick and may drift inland. It forms in conditions of no wind or very light winds. It will be dispersed by an increase/decrease in wind speed or change of direction. It will also be dispersed if the water becomes colder or the air becomes warmer (the temperature difference reduces). To look at each option: "Radiation cooling and the creation of a ground inversion." This means that the low-level air is getting colder, which would not dissipate the sea smoke. "Calm winds, allowing the build-up of high-level stratus clouds." Calm winds allow the formation of sea smoke, and high level clouds do not really affect it. "Inflow of warm air at higher levels, reducing relative humidity." High level changes do not affect sea smoke formation/dissipation. It is a low-level phenomenon only. "Inflow of unstable air, dissipating any surface inversion." This is correct. Unstable air without a surface inversion will be warmer near the surface, so the sea smoke will dissipate as the air temperature rises above the dewpoint.

learning.explanation: When air temperature increases with increasing altitude, it causes absolutely stable atmospheric stratification. content.question:
Your destination aerodrome in Western Europe lies on the crest of a ridge, inland, with an elevation of 700 feet AMSL.
Before take-off, the METAR for your destination is: "0850Z 27015KT 0100 R29/0650 FG VV/// 03/03 Q1005"
There is another aerodrome a few miles west of the destination aerodrome at an elevation of 200 feet AMSL.
The METAR for this aerodrome is: "0850Z 26011KT 9999 SCT0500 05/03 Q1005".
Considering this situation, what type of fog is present at the destination aerodrome and which of these statement correctly describes the dissipation of this fog?

options.B: Orographic fog; and as the temperature rises with diurnal heating, the fog is likely to lift into cloud.

options.D: Advection fog; and diurnal heating will increase the wind speed to lift the fog into a low-level layer of stratus cloud.

key_points: This is a very clear case of Orographic Fog (Hill Fog)
The higher elevation destination aerodrome is colder than the nearby lower-level aerodrome
This means that the destination temperature has reached the dewpoint of 3⁰C, and cloud has formed, which is referred to as hill fog, or orographic fog
learning.explanation: This is a very clear case of Orographic Fog (Hill Fog). The higher elevation destination aerodrome is colder than the nearby lower-level aerodrome. This means that the destination temperature has reached the dewpoint of 3⁰C, and cloud has formed, which is referred to as hill fog, or orographic fog. This type of fog, as previously mentioned, is actually just a normal cloud which is currrently touching the terrain, and will lift as the ground warms up throughout the day.

key_points: Cumulus clouds form primarily through the process of convection
It begins when the Earth's surface is heated by the sun, warming the air just above it
Warm air is lighter and less dense than cool air, so it begins to rise
learning.explanation: Cumulus clouds form primarily through the process of convection. It begins when the Earth's surface is heated by the sun, warming the air just above it. Warm air is lighter and less dense than cool air, so it begins to rise. As the warm air rises, it cools adiabatically (without gaining or losing heat), and when it reaches its dew point temperature (the temperature at which air becomes saturated with moisture), water vapor starts to condense into tiny water droplets. These droplets cluster together to form visible cumulus clouds. These clouds can grow rapidly, when the atmosphere is unstable, with no upper-air inversion, and may develop into cumulonimbus clouds, with their tops reaching the tropopause. The vertical extent of cumulus clouds is limited by the stability of the atmosphere. If the atmosphere is stable, meaning that the temperature increases with height (inversion). A subsidence inversion occurs when there is a layer of sinking or subsiding air in the atmosphere. This sinking air warms adiabatically (without heat exchange) as it descends, causing a temperature increase with height. This warm layer acts as a lid or cap on the rising warm air, preventing it from ascending further.

content.question: Fog or mist will start to form when the air becomes saturated, this may happen when: Temperature (1) _____ to the dew point temperature and/or there is (2) _____ in dew point temperature to that of the air temperature.

key_points: Dew, fog or clouds form when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into liquid water

For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated (Relative Humidity = 100%) - which means that the air parcel is unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense
There are two ways by which saturation is reached: (a) By increasing the water content in the air
learning.explanation: Dew, fog or clouds form when the invisible water vapour in the air condenses into liquid water. For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated (Relative Humidity = 100%) - which means that the air parcel is unable to hold all the water it contains in vapour form, so it starts to condense. There are two ways by which saturation is reached: (a) By increasing the water content in the air. I.e. through evaporation, to a point where the air can hold no more. (b) By cooling the air so that it reaches its dew point - this is the temperature at which condensation occurs, and is unable to "hold" any more water. The dew point is always lower than (or equal to) the air temperature => If the air temperature cools to the dew point, or if the dew point rises to equal the air temperature, then water vapour condenses and dew, fog or clouds begin to form. At this point where the dew point temperature equals the air temperature, the relative humidity is 100%. For condensation to occur, temperature must equal dew point.

content.question:
In a situation with a high relative humidity, the cloud base is located relatively ___ and its top is situated where the ___ meets the ___.
Fill in the blanks.

key_points: To have a rough idea on the Cloud Base height, we can refer to the following formula: (Air temperature at surface – dew point temperature) x 400 A general rule of thumb is that the wider the gap between the temperature and dew point, the higher the cloud base is likely to be
When temperature rises during the day, dew point spread will increase and cloud base will be higher
When Relative Humidity is low, you would expect a HIGH cloud base
learning.explanation: To have a rough idea on the Cloud Base height, we can refer to the following formula: (Air temperature at surface – dew point temperature) x 400 A general rule of thumb is that the wider the gap between the temperature and dew point, the higher the cloud base is likely to be. When temperature rises during the day, dew point spread will increase and cloud base will be higher. When Relative Humidity is low, you would expect a HIGH cloud base. On the other hand, a lower difference between temperature and dew point (and, consequently, High Relative Humidity), leads to a LOWer cloud base. To calculate cloud tops, we need to know the SALR and ELR => cloud tops are located where SALR meets ELR. Why? Because air in clouds is rising with SALR - air is saturated (moist). Saturated air cools down slower and as long as enough moisture is available the cloud will keep growing. When SALR = ELR (temperature of air parcel in cloud = temperature of environment) the parcel of air cannot ascend (rise) any more because there is no difference in temperature (no difference in density). Hence, top of clouds is defined.

content.question: "Frontal fog" may occur when low cloud covers the surface with the passage of a front, more commonly over hills than over low ground. It may also develop when...

options.A: dust particles blown by strong winds at a cold front become condensation nuclei for water droplets.
options.B: the air becomes saturated by continuous rain falling from warm air above a frontal surface.
options.C: cold air crossing warm, damp ground absorbs water vapour, which then recondenses in the cold air.
options.D: a cold front cools the warm air it displaces, at the surface, to below its dew point.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.04.02.05.01: Explain the formation of frontal fog. Frontal fog is a term that can be used to describe any fog that was caused by frontal activity, so includes the "hill fog" mentioned in the question, which is actually just cloud that is low enough to touch the high ground. The more common definition of frontal fog is a special type of fog that only happens under a warm front, just before it passes. Before a warm front passes, we are in a cold sector, so the air is cold, and therefore the ground is relatively cold as well. There is, however, warmer rain falling from above, at least towards the latter stages of the front passing. This is warm rain falling through cold air, and tends to bring a high amount of humidity to the air it goes through. This humidity is most when the warm rain hits the cold ground and begins to evaporate. At this point, we have a lot of humidity in cold air, which leads to the air becoming quickly saturated, and frontal fog is formed. Sometimes this is complemented by stratus fractus, which are small patches of stratus cloud that hang in the air.

content.question: Which type of inversion can lead to fog formation due to the temperature of air in contact with the surface dropping below its dew point when it contacts a colder surface?

key_points: An inversion in the atmosphere is where temperature rises with an increase in height
This produces extreme stability There are four kinds of inversions: ground, turbulence, subsidence, and frontal

GROUND INVERSION - develops when air is cooled by contact with a colder surface until it becomes cooler than the overlying atmosphere; this occurs most often on clear nights, when the ground cools off rapidly by radiation
learning.explanation: An inversion in the atmosphere is where temperature rises with an increase in height. This produces extreme stability There are four kinds of inversions: ground, turbulence, subsidence, and frontal. GROUND INVERSION - develops when air is cooled by contact with a colder surface until it becomes cooler than the overlying atmosphere; this occurs most often on clear nights, when the ground cools off rapidly by radiation. If the temperature of surface air drops below its dew point, fog may result. TURBULENCE INVERSION - often forms when quiescent air overlies turbulent air. Within the turbulent layer, vertical mixing carries heat downward and cools the upper part of the layer. The unmixed air above is not cooled and eventually is warmer than the air below; an inversion then exists. SUBSIDENCE INVERSION - develops when a widespread layer of air descends. The layer is compressed and heated by the resulting increase in atmospheric pressure, and, as a result, the lapse rate of temperature is reduced. If the air mass sinks low enough, the air at higher altitudes becomes warmer than at lower altitudes, producing a temperature inversion. FRONTAL INVERSION - occurs when a cold air mass undercuts a warm air mass and lifts it aloft; the front between the two air masses then has warm air above and cold air below.

key_points: Cumulus clouds are formed through the process of convection

The trigger for the formation of cumulus clouds is heating from below
learning.explanation: Cumulus clouds are formed through the process of convection. Convection involves the vertical movement of air masses, particularly the rising of warm air. The trigger for the formation of cumulus clouds is heating from below. This heating can occur due to the warming of the Earth's surface by sunlight. As the surface heats up, it warms the air above it. When this warm air rises, it cools and condenses to form cumulus clouds. The vertical growth of cumulus clouds is restricted by a subsidence inversion. A subsidence inversion occurs when descending air in the atmosphere creates a layer of warmer air above cooler air. This layer acts as a barrier to vertical air movement, preventing further upward growth of the cumulus cloud. It inhibits the vertical development of the cloud, leading to the characteristic flattened appearance of cumulus clouds.

learning.explanation: CUMULUS HUMILIS, often referred to as "fair weather cumulus", are cumuliform clouds with little vertical extent, common in the summer - formed by local heating of the surface, even in a stable atmosphere. They are fairly distinct and easy to classify in relation to other clouds: they’re a cumulus cloud that’s wider than tall. They’re flattened cumulus and are generally found low in altitude. Its vertical growth is usually restricted by the existence of a temperature inversion in the atmosphere - cooling of the surface stops convection and increases stability in the airmass which causes clouds to dissipate. Within the cloud, ascending currents of about 2–5 m/s (7–17 ft/s) may be encountered. Turbulence is sometimes severe, especially during the formation and growth of the cloud, and it diminishes when the cloud is mature. Air below the cloud base can be quite turbulent due to the thermals that formed the clouds, giving occupants of light aircraft an uncomfortable ride. To avoid turbulence where such clouds are present, pilots may climb above the cloud tops.

The small amount of evaporation from the sea is enough to cause saturation and condensation in the air close to the surface. key_points: In an unstable air mass, cumulus clouds will often form during the day, particularly due to surface heating, causing localised thermal uplift and then convection due to the instability of the air mass

When the Sun becomes lower in the sky in an evening, the solar heating on the ground decreases, which reduces thermal uplift, as well as reducing low level heating of the air mass, which increases the stability of the air mass
All this reduces the convection of cumulus clouds, and gradually stops them growing any further, or new ones forming
learning.explanation: In an unstable air mass, cumulus clouds will often form during the day, particularly due to surface heating, causing localised thermal uplift and then convection due to the instability of the air mass. When the Sun becomes lower in the sky in an evening, the solar heating on the ground decreases, which reduces thermal uplift, as well as reducing low level heating of the air mass, which increases the stability of the air mass. All this reduces the convection of cumulus clouds, and gradually stops them growing any further, or new ones forming. Sometimes, if there have been large CB clouds formed during the late afternoon, they will have enough momentum and energy left in them to continue producing thunderstorms into the late evening and night.

When droplets from freezing fog freeze onto surfaces, a white deposit of feathery ice crystals is formed. This is referred to as rime; rime is a characteristic of freezing fog and is often seen on vertical surfaces exposed to the wind.

key_points: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of clouds, preventing further upward convection
Essentially, the vertical development of clouds, determined by humidity and temperature differences between the cloud and the surroundings, is influenced
If the air temperature equals or exceeds the cloud's temperature, cloud growth ceases
learning.explanation: In the troposphere, inversions cause an increase in stability and tend to limit the upward growth of clouds, preventing further upward convection. Essentially, the vertical development of clouds, determined by humidity and temperature differences between the cloud and the surroundings, is influenced. If the air temperature equals or exceeds the cloud's temperature, cloud growth ceases. In simple terms, a temperature inversion is a thin layer of the atmosphere where the normal decrease in temperature with height reverses, leading to temperature increases with height. It acts as a lid, inhibiting the typical convective overturning of the atmosphere from penetrating through the inversion.

learning.explanation: Lenticular clouds (cloud type lenticularis) are clouds which are shaped like a lens, and they stay in the same location, even though the wind in their location is strong. They are indicative of the presence of mountain waves, and look very smooth, but actually contain lots of windshear and turbulence nearby and within them. Wind rotors exist in the region of lenticular clouds, and sometimes have associated roll/rotor clouds, which are also indicative of severe turbulence. "Stratocumulus clouds": stratocumulus clouds are generally stable and not known for causing severe turbulence. "Nimbostratus clouds": Nimbostratus clouds are typically associated with steady, widespread precipitation and often have a layered structure. While these clouds may cause areas of light to moderate turbulence, severe turbulence is less likely as they are generally more stable. "Cirrocumulus clouds": Cirrocumulus clouds are high-altitude clouds composed of small white, fluffy cloudlets. They are usually not associated with severe turbulence as they form at high levels and typically indicate stable atmospheric conditions.
